info.name: pvsz testing
info.description: All data with {{}} including {{token}}, {{plant}} and {{group}} are variables generated by login, add a new plant and add a new Group respectively.

exec: pm.test("Request is successful with a status code of 201", function () {
pm.test("Request is successful with a status code of 200", function () {

response.name: Login failed (password incorrect)
Login failed (user not found)

item.name: List all plants in the library

exec: pm.test("Request is successful with a status code of 200", function () {

response.name: Success
response.body:
{
    "data": [
        {
            "_id": "63229082cb8e6da5c0483d95",
            "botanicalName": "Epipremnum aureum 'Pearls and Jade'",
            "commonName": "Pearls and jade pothos ",
            "family": "Araceae ",
            "plantType": "Perennial, vine ",
            "matureSize": "6-10 ft. long (indoors) ",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "2",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-draining ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic ",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer ",
            "flowerColor": "Green, white ",
            "hardinessZones": "9-12, USA ",
            "nativeArea": "South Pacific ",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "These variegated plants are known for being slow-growing and easy to care for. For the most part, their care is similar to many of their relatives in the Epipremnum genus, although there are some key differences. Most notably, pearls and jade pothos do not tolerate low light conditions as well as other pothos varieties such as the golden pothos or jade pothos. It is also important to know that while these plants are capable of flowering, it is extremely uncommon for them to flower when grown indoors so don’t fret if your plant is not giving you any blooms!",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/SD2HXDr_avFq3Ovn0vAR2uRJOmc=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/pearls-and-jade-pothos-hero-d37a849aff364f73af828eab8af594c6.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322c9445e3296210f965ff1",
            "botanicalName": "Alocasia macrorrhiza ‘Stingray’ ",
            "commonName": "Alocasia stingray ",
            "family": "Araceae ",
            "plantType": "Perennial, corm ",
            "matureSize": "3-4 ft. tall (indoors), 3-4 ft. wide (indoors); 15 ft. tall (outdoors), 8 ft. wide (outdoors) ",
            "sunExposure": "1 ",
            "waterPeriod": "3",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-draining ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic ",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer ",
            "flowerColor": "Green, white ",
            "hardinessZones": "9-11, USA ",
            "nativeArea": "Asia ",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "Caring for the Alocasia stingray is similar to most of its relatives in the Alocasia genus. It appreciates warm, humid conditions and dappled sunlight. For those who tend to underwater their plants, this houseplant likely isn’t the best choice as it requires consistent moisture in order to thrive. As with all Alocasias, it is common for the Alocasia stingray to go dormant and lose all of its leaves in the fall and winter so don’t panic if this happens to your plant - you haven’t killed it! As long as the corm is still firm and healthy your plant will come back to life in the spring when temperatures warm and the daylight hours lengthen again. ",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/0qcUq0RI5yAT04of7UGNxi27hq4=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/how-to-grow-alocasia-stingray-hero-66d8a000b48742e9a5e8d5f89f536d45.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322cad15e3296210f965ff2",
            "botanicalName": "Alocasia silver dragon",
            "commonName": "Alocasia baginda 'Silver Dragon'",
            "family": "Araceae ",
            "plantType": "Herbaceous, Perennial",
            "matureSize": "Up to 3 ft. tall",
            "sunExposure": "Partial ",
            "waterPeriod": "2 days",
            "soilType": "Well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Neutral, Alkaline",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer (very occasional)",
            "flowerColor": "White",
            "hardinessZones": "9-11 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "Southeast Asia",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets, toxic to people",
            "growthCare": "Alocasia aren't always the best beginner houseplants, and the silver dragon is no exception. However, your picky plant can thrive if you can offer them the right light, warmth and humidity levels. The key is mimicking their native tropical rainforest conditions as closely as possible.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/z4YcSSTJrfy7WzJXhVBjvcQfoQo=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/GettyImages-1366397696-85f3109698e44a7e81e727216037913b.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322cc9e5e3296210f965ff4",
            "botanicalName": "Alocasia 'Tiny Dancer'",
            "commonName": "Alocasia tiny dancer ",
            "family": "Araceae ",
            "plantType": "Perennial, corm ",
            "matureSize": "14-20 in. tall, 11-18 in. wide ",
            "sunExposure": "1 ",
            "waterPeriod": "3",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-draining ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, neutral ",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer ",
            "flowerColor": "Green, white ",
            "hardinessZones": "10-11, USA ",
            "nativeArea": "Asia",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "Caring for the Alocasia tiny dancer is similar to many other Alocasias, This tropical plant appreciates consistent moisture, warm temperatures, and lots of light. In ideal conditions it grows quickly - pushing out new growth every couple of weeks. As old growth dies off removing it will keep the plant looking clean, but otherwise pruning is not required. An absence of flowering is not cause for concern. Alocasia tiny dancer does not flower readily when grown indoors.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/B2n2pKlVKWdfvVyEgRQPYqYeSHI=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/alocasia-tiny-dancer-guide-5498869-hero-af754367ec78437b88fceedfdeb5bbbd.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322ceff5e3296210f965ff5",
            "botanicalName": "Hoya macrophylla or Hoya latifolia",
            "commonName": "Wax Plant, Honey Plant",
            "family": "Apocynaceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial, Succulent, Vine",
            "matureSize": "Up to 6 ft. tall",
            "sunExposure": "2 ",
            "waterPeriod": "1",
            "soilType": "Well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, neutral ",
            "bloomType": "Summer",
            "flowerColor": "White",
            "hardinessZones": "9-11 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "Asia",
            "toxicity": "None",
            "growthCare": "Letting your plant climb up a trellis encourages more vigorous growth. Other than that, offering a bright, warm position and an infrequent watering schedule should be enough to keep your Hoya macrophylla thriving for years.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/I3iFNxHrqbMszmhDnYkmY-fDeJM=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/2515474014_7db6f58a8f_o-7da4b289bce84fbcbebbc36a41a321ed.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322cf8f5e3296210f965ff6",
            "botanicalName": "Philodendron gloriosum",
            "commonName": "Philodendron gloriosum",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial",
            "matureSize": "Up to 2.5 feet tall",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "3",
            "soilType": "Well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, neutral ",
            "bloomType": "Rarely blooms indoors",
            "flowerColor": "None",
            "hardinessZones": "10-11 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "South America",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to people, toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "As with many philodendron species, don't fuss over your low-maintenance gloriosum too much. Overwatering and overfertilizing are common problems for this plant, leading to foliage discoloration and root rot. But, that doesn't mean you can neglect the Philodendron gloriosum, you still need to consider the light, temperature, and moisture levels to produce a healthy specimen.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/AJXg0MYx9c31QPUhJiiBR_LdzzE=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/philodendron-gloriosum-growing-guide-5272126-hero-d8f6fadcabff46d4a152d0eebb8fe1b5.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322d00b5e3296210f965ff7",
            "botanicalName": "Philodendron birkin",
            "commonName": "Philodendron birkin",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial",
            "matureSize": "Up to 3 ft. tall",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "2",
            "soilType": "Well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, neutral ",
            "bloomType": "None",
            "flowerColor": "None",
            "hardinessZones": "9-11 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "Central America (original species)",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to people, toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "One of the biggest selling points of all types of philodendron is their low-maintenance nature\u2060\u2060—they're popular beginner houseplants. But that doesn't mean you can neglect them. The Philodendron Birkin still needs the right levels of warmth, moisture, and bright, indirect light to thrive and show off its impressive variegation. Just avoid being too attentive\u2060—overfertilization and overwatering aren't this plant's friends.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/Jj7VElAPD726mYisKy9Esgt5OVo=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/philodendron-birkin-growing-guide-5272115-hero-20fa8606f7414c76937ba11c8b72f6f6.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322d0665e3296210f965ff8",
            "botanicalName": "Alocasia zebrina ",
            "commonName": "Zebra plant, zebrina Alocasia, tiger taro (gabing tigre) ",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial, bulb ",
            "matureSize": "3 ft. tall (indoors), 3 ft. wide (indoors) ",
            "sunExposure": "Partial",
            "waterPeriod": "2 days",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-draining ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, neutral ",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer ",
            "flowerColor": "Green, white ",
            "hardinessZones": "10-11, USA ",
            "nativeArea": "Asia ",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "The Alocasia zebrina is a tropical plant in the family Araceae. Although some growers find it hard to keep this plant happy indoors, under the right conditions, it can grow quite happily in most homes. The trick is to understand how it grows in its natural environment and try to mimic those conditions. Think filtered light, consistent moisture, and warm temperatures. Like all plants in the aroid family, the zebrina is a flowering plant although its blooms are not particularly interesting and it is considered rare for it to flower indoors.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/QyvgA-8_5xCQ9f2HtLAIBJlmAlA=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/alocasia-zebrina-hero-eb88de064d1a451b82b8caeee6167422.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6322d0db5e3296210f965ff9",
            "botanicalName": "Scindapsus pictus 'Exotica' ",
            "commonName": "Satin pothos, silver pothos, silver splash pothos, silver philodendron, silver vine ",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Vine ",
            "matureSize": "10 ft. long ",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "2 ",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-draining ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer ",
            "flowerColor": "Green, white ",
            "hardinessZones": "10-12, USA",
            "nativeArea": "Asia ",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "Scindapsus pictus ‘Exotica’ is a slow-growing plant that is known for being fairly low-maintenance and easy to grow. While it is a flowering plant, it is extremely uncommon for the ‘Exotica’ to produce blooms when grown indoors, so don’t fret if you don’t see any flowers on your indoor plant.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/rmkW3laA9fKbwxurF2dX22aZ1Ow=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/scindapsuspictusexotica-hero-b6536a52af2f47f4b96e4eb5041d4079.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "63244455b1ab549f6c4cedf1",
            "botanicalName": "Alocasia maharani ",
            "commonName": "Alocasia grey dragon, African mask maharani ",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial, corm ",
            "matureSize": "14 in. tall (indoors) ",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "2 ",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-draining ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer ",
            "flowerColor": "Green, white ",
            "hardinessZones": "10, USDA ",
            "nativeArea": "Asia ",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "When it comes to Alocasias, caring for the maharani is not much different than caring for other varieties of the houseplant. Some growers find the maharani easier to care for than other varieties like the Alocasia dragon scale. All Alocasias are known for being slightly picky about their growing environments and are not the hardiest houseplants on the block. The most important thing to remember when it comes to their care is that they need consistent moisture to survive indoors. This is not a houseplant that you can forget to water for a couple of weeks at a time! ",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/8e3TGk4bVKQfagD-SyNVkIHM7mM=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/alocasia-maharani-1-45e46b2121ad4d499d9b384782f85af0.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "632444dab1ab549f6c4cedf2",
            "botanicalName": "Ficus elastica 'Tineke'",
            "commonName": "Ficus Tineke, Variegated rubber tree",
            "family": "Moraceae",
            "plantType": "Tree, Perennial",
            "matureSize": "30 feet tall outdoors, 2–10 feet tall indoors",
            "sunExposure": "2",
            "waterPeriod": "2 ",
            "soilType": "Well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, Neutral",
            "bloomType": "Rarely blooms indoor",
            "flowerColor": "None",
            "hardinessZones": "10-12 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "Asia ",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "Providing you can offer your ficus tineke the right light, these plants are a relatively low-maintenance option—ideal if you're a beginner houseplant enthusiast. Dusting the leaves down and rotating the pot every few weeks helps the plant maintain its impressive variegation.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/NZDYCRH-kwRkSpX6xkC_VTmtfEM=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/ficus-tineke-growing-guide-5270992-hero-29f28c12b44d433fa350f34a1b00af3a.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6324455db1ab549f6c4cedf3",
            "botanicalName": "Round-leaved calathea",
            "commonName": "Calathea Orbifolia syn. Geoppertia orbifolia",
            "family": "Marantaceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial, Herbaceous",
            "matureSize": "2-3 ft. tall",
            "sunExposure": "3",
            "waterPeriod": "4",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acid, Neutral, Alkaline",
            "bloomType": "Rarely flowers indoors",
            "flowerColor": "Creamy white inflorescences",
            "hardinessZones": "11b-12b (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "South America ",
            "toxicity": "None",
            "growthCare": "These plants need plenty of attention to thrive, and trying to keep calatheas alive can be a challenge, even for the most experienced plant parents. One of the reasons they're often nurtured in greenhouses is their need for a warm, humid environment. But, if you can mimic the tropical conditions they love, you'll get to appreciate the beauty of the Calathea orbifolia in your own home. Think moisture-laden air, shady positions, and balmy temperatures.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/8C2Xrr5lsNlNkjKZrFfd4TJk7Vo=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/calathea-orbifolia-growing-guide-5270824-hero-2a3b8667f05b40a49b27da573d2486fb.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "63244d99b1ab549f6c4cedf4",
            "botanicalName": "Philodendron hederaceum 'Rio'",
            "commonName": "Philodendron Rio",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Houseplant",
            "matureSize": "Up to 2.5 ft tall, Vines up to 20 ft, long",
            "sunExposure": "Partial sun",
            "waterPeriod": "2 days",
            "soilType": "Well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, Neutral",
            "bloomType": "Doesn't bloom indoors",
            "flowerColor": "None",
            "hardinessZones": "9-11 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "Central America (original species)",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to people, toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "These plants are relatively easy to care for. In fact, too much attention (like overfertilizing and overwatering) can result in discolored leaves and root rot. To maximize the stunning variegation, you need to get the light right (bright but not too direct) and wipe down the leaves every month or so with a damp cloth.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/scaOS8sidWKZsWqtSdtKZsJjBEY=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/philodendron-rio-growing-guide-5235405-hero-4af0521602684922ad38a1195623dd11.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "63244e1cb1ab549f6c4cedf5",
            "botanicalName": "Epipremnum aureum 'Jade'",
            "commonName": "Jade Pothos",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial, Vine",
            "matureSize": "20–40 ft. long, 3–6 ft. wide",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "2 days",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-drained",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, Neutral",
            "bloomType": "Rarely flowers indoors",
            "flowerColor": "None",
            "hardinessZones": "10-12 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "South Pacific",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to people, toxic to pets",
            "growthCare": "Like most other pothos varieties, Epipremnum aureum 'Jade' has a forgiving nature. You should be able to grow it in most rooms in your home, regardless of the light conditions. You can let it climb a trellis (with support) or grow along a shelf. Left to grow, the vines can reach lengths of up to 30-feet long, so occasionally shaking them loose helps prevent them from becoming an entwined tangle.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/NEHzsb-4bTHe6SEJE03Rw8fc8m4=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/jade-pothos-growing-guide-5235402-hero-8375b6cb7df44366ab7d6e8591ee6b53.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "63244f0eb1ab549f6c4cedf7",
            "botanicalName": "Peperomia Obtusifolia",
            "commonName": "Baby rubber plant, pepper face plant",
            "family": "Piperaceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial, Herbaceous",
            "matureSize": "Up to 1 ft. tall",
            "sunExposure": "2",
            "waterPeriod": "3",
            "soilType": "Clay, Sand, Loam",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, Neutral, Alkaline",
            "bloomType": "Periodic through the year",
            "flowerColor": "White",
            "hardinessZones": "10-12 (USDA)",
            "nativeArea": "South America",
            "toxicity": "None",
            "growthCare": "This South American native grows in tropical rainforest areas in its natural habitat, so it prefers a spot in your home where it's humid and the light is bright but indirect. Other than this, it's a fairly forgiving species that's not bothered by many pests or diseases and is a good choice as a beginner's houseplant.",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/Tzh_UgSRvMAQncubXRjaSicqL-0=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/peperomia-obtusifolia-growing-guide-5271088-hero-4b5c709b63414d48b097f8f27102fdf4.JPG"
        },
        {
            "_id": "6324574cb1ab549f6c4cedf8",
            "botanicalName": "Peperomia tetraphylla ",
            "commonName": "Peperomia Hope, Acorn Peperomia, Four-leaved Peperomia ",
            "family": "Piperaceae",
            "plantType": "Perennial",
            "matureSize": "8 in. wide, 12 in. tall ",
            "sunExposure": "2",
            "waterPeriod": "2",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-drained ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic ",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer",
            "flowerColor": "Green, brown ",
            "hardinessZones": "10-12, US ",
            "nativeArea": "Central America, South America",
            "toxicity": "None",
            "growthCare": "Peperomia Hope is a tropical epiphyte with small, succulent-like leaves that enjoys plenty of moisture and bright, indirect light. Compared to other types of Peperomia, the Hope is a slow-growing cultivar. You may notice long, brown and green, spindly spikes protruding from your plant. Don’t be alarmed—these are flowers. While they are underwhelming in appearance, this is a positive sign that your plant is happy and thriving. Some growers remove the flowers in order to redirect the plant’s energy to producing more foliage. This is up to you. Overall, this trailing plant is relatively low-maintenance and perfect for beginners as it can withstand a bit of neglect. ",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/8o1WSlPkbyssWW2eNSOMUenzpmk=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/peperomia-hope-d0e901f943d34be781a03933ebcb711b.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "632457e1b1ab549f6c4cedfa",
            "botanicalName": "Cylindropuntia ",
            "commonName": "Cholla",
            "family": "Cactaceae ",
            "plantType": "Cactus ",
            "matureSize": "None",
            "sunExposure": "1",
            "waterPeriod": "1",
            "soilType": "Sandy, well-drained ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic, neutral ",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer",
            "flowerColor": "Green, red, pink, yellow, orange ",
            "hardinessZones": "5-11, US ",
            "nativeArea": "North America, South America",
            "toxicity": "None",
            "growthCare": "Cholla cacti are known for being hardy, and as long as you can provide them with lots of sunlight, they will be pretty happy. If there is one thing to stay away from when it comes to growing cholla, it’s moisture. These cacti are highly drought-tolerant and can easily succumb to overwatering, especially if they aren’t receiving enough light. ",
            "imageSource": "https://www.thespruce.com/thmb/n4Pmy9xuiWJAHcKmKIa9VmOXPf4=/941x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():format(webp)/grow-cholla-plants-3992047-3-4e19b5ce73fa4f0987b8bb9bc7c3caa6-fb57497535784a7b922f568e66d3fb1b.jpg"
        },
        {
            "_id": "63245860b1ab549f6c4cedfb",
            "botanicalName": "Alocasia micholitziana 'Frydek' ",
            "commonName": "Alocasia frydek, green velvet Alocasia ",
            "family": "Araceae",
            "plantType": "Herbaceous perennial ",
            "matureSize": "2-3 ft. tall, 2-3 ft. wide ",
            "sunExposure": "Partial ",
            "waterPeriod": "2 days",
            "soilType": "Moist but well-drained ",
            "soilpH": "Acidic",
            "bloomType": "Spring, summer",
            "flowerColor": "Green",
            "hardinessZones": "9-11, US",
            "nativeArea": "Asia",
            "toxicity": "Toxic to cats, dogs, and horses",
            "growthCare": "As with many types of Alocasia, keeping the frydek happy indoors can be a challenge. That being said, when given the right conditions, it is possible for the frydek to thrive. One of the most important aspects of caring for this plant is ensuring that it gets enough moisture. These tropical aroids enjoy regular watering, high humidity, and will suffer in dry environments and prolonged periods of drought. ",
